name: Can You Candle It? Candlelit Spots for Romancing

text.text: Can You Candle It? Candlelit Spots for Romancing

Apart from ghouls and vampires, everyone looks their best by candlelight. The waxy glow cleverly hides your blemishes and the gentle golden flicker turns that panicked look in your eye to a seductive twinkle. An open flame is a guaranteed path to a successful date, which is why you so rarely seal the deal at petrol stations. These are some of our favourite spots that are lit by the almighty candle, where you're much less likely to get shot down leaning in for a kiss but a little more likely to catch fire.

tip.text: A stalwart of old Soho, Andrew Edmunds is usually busy with regulars and the odd lucky-striking tourist. Inside the feeling is wooden and rickety but the food shows no signs of falling behind - for starters the likes of burrata served with almonds caught our eye and for mains, the roast quail with charred aubergine, pomegranate and mint added a touch of Middle Eastern flavour to an otherwise very British establishment.

text.text: Andrew Edmunds is that spot in Soho that you've walked past 100 times and said, 'Ooo that looks nice, let's go there next time'. Well now's the time, stud. Let the flicker of the candles in the window draw you in to this neighbourhood gem in an area that hasn't been anyone's neighbourhood for a long time. Excellent food, perfect lighting, and the homeliest of atmospheres makes this an ideal date spot.

tip.text:
The biggest compliment you can hit a cocktail joint with is that it’s where the bartenders drink. That’s the deal with Happiness Forgets: a moody cocktail den lying in wait down the right steps in the right restaurant in Hoxton Square. Sure it ticks the conventional boxes: candle lit, bare bricked and seating only, but this has more about it than an amorous aura; this is about putting the art of cocktail making on a pedestal.

Here some of the friendliest, most knowledgeable staff around concoct unique potions that veer off the usual path, tailor made to suit the tastes of the most particular. Rather than ordering from the drinks list, tell them your story - yeah the whole thing - and see what they give you. But don’t forget to book, because happiness is all the rage right now.

text.text: A lot of bars talk the big talk when it comes to romance, but this is one of the best. The flicker of the candles bounces beautifully off the bare brick walls and dark woods, but they also have the cocktail chops to match. Let the bartender know a bit about you and he'll whip you up the perfect beverage. This is also a great opportunity to humbly up-sell yourself.

tip.text:
There's a lot to love about The Lamb: a candlelit, atmospheric public house that's been serving Holloway scallys since the 1870s. We like to imagine it doesn't look an awful lot different now as it did then, with bare floorboards, candles dimly lighting up the space and restored vintage furniture along with those swoony original green tiles on the facade. There's something about it; an original charm and capable of getting a little raucous but only in the most friendly of ways.

There are plenty of draught ales and lagers from indie breweries, and whilst they don't do food you can order takeaway from the nearby Dough Life and bistro La Muse. Tuesday nights might just be the best night to sample this spot at its liveliest - when live Irish music fills the air, turning it into a hot house.

text.text: With restored vintage furniture, bare wooden floors and candles all over, we like to think this old boozer looks just the same as it did in the 1870s. The vibe at The Lamb on nights when they have musicians is one of the most atmospheric experiences available in North London, and certainly in Holloway.

tip.text: Probably the original spot for a date, this is the oldest wine bar in London with a reputation for excellent cheese platters and an incredible selection of wines to sample. But the best part is simply the candle-lit cellar setting. Go to do a little romancing here and let us know how it goes. But if it all goes terribly, we had no part in any of it. Oh, and it gets super busy on weekends so get down there early.

text.text: The vaulted ceilings of what is supposedly London's oldest wine bar have seen many an intimate smooch. With acoustics and claustrophobia working hand-in-hand to bring people physically closer together, the excellent wines and cheeses do the rest of the leg work, leaving you to do the last 5%.

tip.text:
Before passing the doors at Spurstowe Arms, take a quick look and make sure you’re wearing your Sunday best. Because the Hackneyites who typically frequent this one seem to generally be a) well-dressed and b) pretty damn attractive. If that doesn't deter, or you fancy yourself up to assimilating, you'll find a super cosy, aged tavern with plenty of vintage charm.

A one room joint dominated by a central bar, you'll spot fresh flowers, candles, wonky lights, refurbished mirrors, vintage paintings and art deco posters. It's effortlessly cool, silently saying, 'Oh what, this thing? We just found it’. There are a few ales on tap but nothing out of the ordinary, and the food is pointed towards gastro, with bar food, sharing boards and a couple of mains changing each month.

What this is, though, is either the physical embodiment of a hangover cure or a venue for a group chill, where you can get together either in the walled - and often busy - beer garden out back, or on a candlelit corner table and enjoy a booze-aided commune.

text.text: Taking a candlelit corner of this Hackney boozer, surrounded by the well dressed and well sexy folk of London Fields, should set the tone for romance nicely. And if it doesn't, there is just enough bespoke furniture and quirky decorations for you to fill the conversation until home time.

tip.text:
From the cobbled streets out front, primed for a shady espresso on a hot summer’s day; to the semi-open courtyard behind stable doors overlooking the kitchen; to the space in the back where pasta is rolled in front of stacks of firewood by a woman who ‘learnt it from her nonna’, this is maybe London’s most authentically rustic Italian restaurant. It’s the kind of aesthetic that 100 ad-men on 100 working lunches would never be able to recreate. It’s what Dr. Oetker would have done his PHD in before devising the Ristorante range of ‘authentic Italian pizzas’. It’s what our Monday morning Southern Italian escape fantasies are made of. It’s like if Call Me By Your Name had a baby with that shot of David Gandy on the boat in Capri. In short, it’s absolutely beautiful.

And yes, the food is also fantastic. Fresh pastas made in the next room blanched to al dente perfection; deceptively simple salads served in terracotta bowls; and straight forward but expertly cooked mains like roast chicken, garlic and potatoes ooze flavour and charm. And their lunchtime deal of two courses and a glass of wine for £15 isn't too bad either.

text.text: This is Hackney's most charming Italian restaurant with cobbled streets out front and a simple menu of beautifully rustic dishes, so it'll come as no surprise that come evening the place lightens up with wax-based ambience. Slurping from a shared bowl of tagliatelle whilst locking eyes with bae is a one way ticket to bone-town.

tip.text:
How many pubs can you step outside of and actually hear the river splashing against the wooden slats below your feet? The Mayflower is a 400 year-old, dark, musty pub that has barely changed throughout its history, and it's all the better for it. Head outside to the jetty, where the water has been known to soak a foot or two, or upstairs to the safety of the restaurant where the views are even better.

The ale selection is great with a range that features Camden Brewery, Meantime, BrewDog and other medium-sized breweries. The food menu is pretty ordinary pub fare, but cheaper than you'd expect in this day and age (about £12 for mains). There's an open fireplace to cosy up by in winter and the aforementioned decking over the Thames for when it gets warm, just be prepared to fight for your spot when it does.

text.text: Stepping in to the oldest pub on the Thames, you worry that the open candles are gonna send it up in flames with all its blackened wooden beams and low ceilings. But life is about risks and these guys have kept it going for 400 years. Grab a seat by the window, if possible, and watch the river drift by through the sooty glass and candle smoke.

tip.text:
Wine, cheese and charcuterie. It's a combination that's been tried and tested in the likes of Clapham, but what say the good folk of Camberwell? Can't say we're not partial to a glass of vino, and throw in some nibbles, low lighting and a little live music and you've got yourself a real good recipe for romance.

Good Neighbour's menu offers quality cheese and cured meats in varying selections, pizzette (that's mini pizza, guys), and a tidy selection of seasonal small plates. We slithered our way through a mighty sultry baked camembert with rosemary, orange zest and roast garlic, but you might be feeling the pork rillettes, or black miso aubergine and feta - in such uncertain times, who are we to say?

text.text: Wine, cheese, charcuterie and candles... if you can't close here that's on you. We've got this pegged as one of the sultriest spots in South, and if you happen to catch some live music too, you're on to a winner. Get adventurous with some wines you haven't tried before and then hopefully get adventurous back at the crib.

tip.text: Left exactly as it was when he died, the house of 19th century architect John Soane is a three-house-wide labyrinth of curiosities. On display are an incredible array of famous artworks, sculptures, furniture and artefacts. If you have limited time be sure to check out the sarcophagus of the Egyptian king and the picture room in which the famous painted series 'The Rake's Progress' by William Hogarth hangs. But don't come with limited time - everything is worth swooning over for quite a while. Plus it's all free, bro.

text.text: For something slightly different, head to Sir John Soane's old gaff on the last Friday of the month for a candlelit late. Roaming the halls after dark adds a whole new sense of mystery to the already pretty mysterious place. You can play 'seductive strangers at a bougie 1920s mansion party' with boo.
